title: Which Region Is Your Favorite?
body: I left out Mt. Targon and The Void due to space issues... But lets talk about it. Mt. Targon is my personal favorite.

replies.body:
Bilgewater has the single most interesting story event that has happened in the game’s history. Even if the more recent work has been taking it to be about stuff I don’t care about. 

Demacia has all the trappings of a setting I want to see explored. The only problem is so far it isn’t interesting. I want to read about soldiers, knights, economic struggles, and war. Instead they've mostly focused on Lux and how bad mages are treated. And I don’t really care.  It’s not helped by the fact that J4 is probably the least interesting leader character in the game. When compared to Swain, Azir, Gangplank/MF, and the 3 Queens the only thing I can say about J4 is that he has a dragon girlfriend. So... good for him, I guess.

Shyv and J4 is not even really canon. His new version has the problem of lack of characterization. I saw something TBSkyen pointed is that Jarvan who grew up all his life in this anti-magic racist society suddenly trusts Shyvana out of nowhere and that instead of trying to go more into that they gloss over it in favour of world building and tying it to Shyvana’s lore. He also brings up the problem we never get to know Jarvan as a person or character. The last problem pointed out that I agree with is a contradiction in his motivation. We’re told at the start the reason why he decided to attack the Noxians even though it was unwise to do so was because of the tragedies he saw happen to his people. Then at the end they say Jarvan learned unity instead of thinking wars was about victory and gloriousness but at the beginning the reason he attacked the Noxian wasn’t out of pride or his reputation but because he got sad over what happened to his people. So which one is it suppose to be? Is it suppose to be “Oh God what will they think about me at home for losing! I can’t go back to Demacia like this! They’ll mock me! I must win at all cost as victory is what matters!” Or “Oh God look at all the bloodshed the vile Noxian caused and the poor people who suffered! I have to avenge them and make Noxians pay!” These two are very different characters.

I suggest everyone to watch TBSkyen lore videos, they are so good at seeing specific problems and specific reasons why a short story is so well-written.

"Gloss over" isn't exactly how I would describe J4 and Shyv's relationship being represented in-lore. The fault for this perception of it being rushed lies more on the restrictions all Biographies have. The biggest thing being Bio's have a third-person narration to them, which is godawful for conveying and contextualizing emotional scenarios or any part of a character's internal thoughts/struggles. If J4 and Shyv's potential partnership (romantic or not) was to ever be told, the Biography wouldn't be the most advantageous place to do that. But Bio's can be used to establish it, which is exactly what the writers did.

But it is glossed over. His trust of her and their friendship is not explained well., it’s even worse give J4’s background. We are just suppose to accept it. Watch this video where TBSkyen will go line by line what’s wrong with it and why it makes Jarvan seem so dull even though there was potential.

https://youtube.com/watch?v=KfTman7qrlc

Some of the other bios establish the CHARACTER well, Jarvan’s fail heavily on this.

The other issues that can arise are the limited word count that each biography is given, something between 580-700 words (which isn't a hell-of-a-lot). Although both of the two characters did get the advantage of overlapping backstory, yet each still originated from wildly different backgrounds, where the writer has to fill that word count by juggling all the aspects of their 'origins' into a short catalog structured story. At the same time pushing the other plotline that gets the two characters teaming up in a sufficiently explained, sufficiently detailed and sufficiently satisfying story all in an individual Bio of about 10-13 paragraphs. 

I think they did it as lucrative a job as they could possibly do under such conditions.

It has nothing to do with word count. When this bio was released, it was at a time where biographies didn’t have a limited word count. Now Riot arrative team imposed a word count because of the messy biographies like Jarvan. And shorter biographies in League have done a far better job at establishing character. Did you watch the video? Because you wouldn’t say it’s adequately explained. There is also a problem of a literal contradiction in the little character he was shown to have. How can you defend this? Lets go even further, Jarvan’s colour story does nothing for him either.
North America. The story is really fleshed out, there's lots of interesting conflict within the region, and there's some hidden gems underneath the thickening plot.

So, I like Runeterra as a whole (I'm the definition of biased) but getting down to region level, I'd have to go with Zaun, Bilgewater, and Shurima, in that order.  Everything else is a bit further behind than those three.

Zaun for its bruised pride, irreverent youth culture, and bottomless ingenuity.  I like how Zaun is just so bloody minded about _living_.
Bilgewater for its mix of outsiders and the Buhru people, for its precarious livability, and for its depth of superstition and traditions.
Shurima for its incredible history (hrm, maybe bruised pride again?), its harsh and beautiful landscape, and the sheer potential of its people to return to their cultural, intellectual, and societal greatness (and then surpass it).

(FRELJORD) After living in texas for many years of my life I find that the colder weather suits me, and I like their methodical avalanche feel of an unstoppable force when moved and bother. The amount of cc that the champs have in game is also pretty cool adds to the theme of power and force in my eyes

Freljord, and specifically the Avarosans.  The beauty of its southern, forested mountains.  The thousands of years of history.  The chance to see a region united by peace and humanity.  The lair of the Watchers—and where they must be stopped.

Anyone could live out their lives in one of its valleys.  No Demacian or Noxian to trample you.  None of Zaun or the Shadow Isles’ gloom and fear.  No Ionian or Shuriman mages and maniacs on the loose.  Piltover’s for the rich and ruthless, while Bandle City’s for Yordles only.  In the Avarosan Freljord, one could have clean air, a clean conscience, and a warm, safe home for oneself and family.

It kind of took me by surprise, but I've begun to appreciate Ionia as it's lore has changed. I find its present iteration very fascinating. The Noxian invasion was more than era of violence, it disrupted the entire continent from the physical landscape to its spiritual core. It's people are fragmented, traditions are being challenged by new ideals, and its magical essence has become twisted. It's like a body fighting off an infection, but it's harming itself in the process of recovery.

Noxus satisfies both my craving for dark fantasy and my passion for the problems of postmodernism.  I think the storytelling opportunities it offers are infinite, unfortunately not that well explored yet.

Second place and first place for a very long time was Icathia.

Really hard to chose between Piltover and Zaun, I love them both.
I wish they would give Piltover more champions, I love the Victorian and steampunk thematic and there is so much they could do with it. I will just give Zaun the edge here since it is more defined (more champions and therefore more stories told).

Noxus is everything I want from a fantasy world. Characters who don't fight for good but for what they believe in, which in turn leads to the question of what is right and wrong. A brutal hierarchy that rewards strength and merit of different forms (the principals of strength), and that while it is flawed, the possibility still exists. The ideas of possible political subterfuge to invade/ destabilize other countries. The characters in Noxus are constantly tested, and I love seeing them rise to the challenge.

Second place goes to Demacia, I really like the insular specialist nation. I really like other regions like Freljord and Bilgewater, but not on the same level as Noxus.
The Void isn't a region, it's a dimension, and Piltover and Zaun are basically together now, so you could have added Mt. Targon.

Shurima. The combination of a once-great nation that is starting to grow back to its former glory, the whole Ascended story-arc, and the fact that it has so many interesting things make it my favourite region alongside Noxus

I'd start out in Bilgewater, exploring the beauty and danger of the sea and her port town. The seafarer superstitions, the sneaky underbelly, the moonlit portside and the seedy gangs. The shipbuilders, the slaughterdocks, the taverns and the waterfalls. The city's unique composition and the old ships reconstructed into it's buildings.

And of course, I'd be sure to pay the tithe

I really liked the Blessed Isles. Before it fell to ruination the architecture and cultural philosophy is just so... elegant, spiritual and mysterious. It really bums me out to know what happened there. Like {{champion:429}}  says in game, "this land was so beautiful..."

Mt. Targon is my favorite region as well, I am a big fan of mythology, I really like the idea of gods, demigods and heroes of legend interacting with each other. I'm hoping to see Mt. Targon develop more in that direction as a region, as currently it feels as though they solely exist to oppose the Void.

I also main Pantheon, although the reason was simply because he is a spartan. Even had he not been written into an Aspect in the new lore, I think his lore would have delivered well as a legendary hero similar to Achilles or Jason from actual Greek mythology.

****

I also really liked the idea of the Sunborn from ancient Shurima as well, so second place may be the Darkin for me, but not Shurima as a whole.

Personally, it wasn't listed and it *technically* isn't a region anymore but, Icathia. "Where Icathia Once Stood" was AN AMAZING story. I want to learn so much more about Icathia and Zilean's struggle to resurrect the city. I want to hear about why Shurima wanted the state so badly and I want to hear about the ins and outs of politics and I want to hear about the the mage kings that ruled. I want to hear about the Kohari and Saijax's relationship with others in the city. Just.. *god*. I wish, I wish, I wish.

I think it's pretty telling that Bandle City has no votes while Ionia has the most, at the moment. I mean it’s still a pretty small survey (I'd actually be interested in the results of an official Riot one), but as the least and most developed factions, respectively, it may just be that some regions need more love than other more fleshed out ones to truly resonate with more players.
Piltover/Zaun should be one option since they're really sub-regions of each other.
